Project Number: 54326-002 
Transaction Technical Assistance (TRTA) 
October 2021 
Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste: Preparing  
the East to South Coast Road Connectivity Project 
and Strengthening the Road Sector Institutional 
Capacity  
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

The currency unit of Timor-Leste is the United States dollar.

  ESRCP  –  East to South Coast Road Connectivity Project 
  F-TRTA  –  transaction technical assistance facility

NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars.

I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  The ensuing East to South Coast Road Connectivity Project (ESRCP) will support the 
government of Timor-Leste’s transport sector priorities to enhance connectivity to markets and 
services and its social and national development agenda, through (i) rehabilitating and upgrading 
about 173.7 kilometers (km) of national road sections in east and south coast areas, (ii) improving 
road asset management, and (iii) strengthening awareness of road safety and gender-related 
issues. The ESRCP is estimated to cost $180.0 million. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will 
provide financing in an amount equivalent to $110.0 million from its ordinary capital resources 
and $35.0 million from concessional loan. The government will finance $35.0 million including 
taxes and duties.  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  The proposed transaction technical assistance (TA) will help the government to prepare 
and implement the ESRCP, particularly on: (i) safeguards analysis and documentation; and (ii) 
institutional and project management capacity development. The TA will supplement another 
transaction TA facility (F-TRTA), the Southeast Asia Transport Project Preparatory Facility, which 
has already been approved. The F-TRTA will support ESRCP through recruitment of (i) consulting 
firm which will conduct the feasibility study and due diligence on engineering, economic and 
financial assessments, social and gender development, and procurement, and (ii) the individual 
consultants who will conduct the tasks to meet the government’s urgent needs (i.e. biodiversity 
specialist, replacement cost and appraisal specialist, and procurement specialist).1 The individual 
consultants under the proposed TA will fully coordinate the work with the consulting firm under 
the F-TRTA. The proposed TA has been included in the country operations business plan for 
Timor-Leste, 2020–2022.2 
 
3.  The proposed TA will recruit individual environmental and social safeguards consultants 
to undertake environmental and social safeguards studies to help the government prepare the 
ESRCP. More specifically, the individual consultants will (i) conduct environmental safeguards 
due diligence including preparation of environmental impact assessment or initial environment 
examination; (ii) prepare climate change assessment, and (iii) undertake social safeguards due 
diligence including preparation of the resettlement plan and the ethnic group development plan. 
Further, the TA will recruit individual consultants to help develop the capacity of the government 
to implement the  ESRCP for  such  areas  as  (i)  livelihood  restoration  and  development,  (ii) 
indigenous peoples assessment, (iii) financial management and accounting, and (iv) overall 
project management.  
 
4.  For the output of safeguards analysis and documentation preparation for the ESRCP, the 
TA consultants will carry out (i) the due diligence for existing studies for Lautem–Com and 
Lautem–Lospalos  road  sections,  and  (ii)  the  feasibility  study  for  Lospalos  –Viqueque  and 
Viqueque–Natabora  road  sections  (Table  1).  The  government  has  prepared  initial  detailed 
engineering design (DED), and preliminary environmental and social safeguards studies for two 
road sections (Lautem–Com section and Lautem–Lospalos section), which need further due 
diligence and design review to make the project ready for ADB financing. For the south coast road 
 
1   Asian Development Bank. 2019. Technical Assistance Report. Southeast Asia Transport Project Preparatory Facility 
Phase 2. Manila. 
2  Asian Development Bank. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan, Timor-Leste, 2020-2022. Manila.

2 
section (Lospalos–Viqueque and Viqueque–Natabora sections), a new feasibility study is needed, 
while the DED for the Lospalos–Viqueque and Viqueque–Natabora section will be conducted 
under the existing loan (e.g. Baucau to Viqueque Highway Project) after the conduct of feasibility 
study. 
 
                                             Table 1: List of Road Candidates 
Assumed 
No.  Section  Length*  Remarks 
(in kilometers) 
1  Lautem– Com  20.8  Previous studies available** 
2  Lautem–Lospalos  27.8  Previous studies available** 
3  Lospalos–Viqueque  125.1   
4  Viqueque–Natabora  50.0   
* Kilometers will be further confirmed during the TA inception phase. 
** Previous studies include the detailed engineering design and preliminary environmental and social 
safeguards studies, which need to be further reviewed and updated. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
5.  Output 1: Safeguards analysis and documentation prepared.  The environmental and 
social  safeguards  studies  will  include  the  environmental  assessment,  poverty  and  social 
assessment, land acquisition and resettlement plan, stakeholder communication strategy, and 
consultation  and  community  engagement  plans.  The  ESRCP  will  be  designed  taking  into 
consideration  the  following:  climate  change  and  disaster  resilience,  sensitive  social  and 
environmental safeguards, gender mainstreaming, the need for paying attention to the ethnic 
minorities issues, obtaining broad community support of impacted ethnic minority communities 
and documentation of the same. 
 
6.   Output 2: Institutional capacity strengthened. The institutional capacity of relevant 
staff under the Ministry of Public Works will be strengthened for such areas as (i) livelihood 
restoration and development, (ii) indigenous peoples assessment, (iii) financial management and 
accounting, and (iv) overall project management. Capacity building needs will be assessed, 
training program and on-the-job training will be planned and conducted, and reporting including 
the lessons learned will be prepared. Modalities of trainings and workshops will depend on the 
coronavirus  disease  pandemic  situation.  If  limited  in-country,  face-to-face  trainings  for 
government officials are not feasible, it will be conducted via online. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
7.  The TA is estimated to cost $ 1.0 million, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 7). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 
1.  
 
8.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, office supplies and other in-kind contributions. The government was informed 
that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
9.  ADB will select, supervise, and evaluate the consultants, and procure goods. ADB will hire 
individual consultants to provide the consultancy services to ensure integrated project delivery.

3 
The TA subproject include procurement of office equipment and furniture and materials for 
workshops. The TA will be implemented over 26 months and is expected to commence no later 
than October 2021.  
 
10.  Implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 2.

ADB = Asian Development Bank, CAFI = Conselho de Administração do Fundo Infraestrutura (Council for the 
Administration of the Infrastructure Fund); DRBFC = Directorate of Roads, Bridges and Flood Control, ICS = Individual 
Consultants Selection, MPW = Ministry of Public Works, Transport and Communications, PMU = project management 
unit, TA = technical assistance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank 
 
11.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy and Regulations for Goods, Works, Non consulting and Consulting Services (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and its associated staff instructions.3  
 
 
 
3  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).
